H0.text: Slump leaves behind crescent‑shaped scars on a hillside and may be caused by a layer of slippery, wet clay underneath the rock and soil on the hillside.

H1.text: Creep leaves behind crescent-shaped scars on a hillside and may be caused by a layer of slippery, wet clay underneath the rock and soil on the hillside.

H2.text: Slide leaves behind crescent-shaped scars on a hillside and may be caused by a layer of slippery, wet clay underneath the rock and soil on the hillside.

H3.text: Shearing leaves behind crescent-shaped scars on a hillside and may be caused by a layer of slippery, wet clay underneath the rock and soil on that hillside.

A4.text: Clay, fine sand and silt, and fine‑grained, pyroclastic material are all susceptible to earthflows.

A5.text: These flows are usually controlled by the pore water pressures within the mass, which should be high enough to produce a low shearing resistance.
